bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Wickliffe Rose, December 7, 1922

div1.p: [Carter] comments on alleged yellow fever cases in Ceara, Brazil.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Wickliffe Rose, December 7, 1922
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
Brazil
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
Dec. 7/22.
Dr. Wickliffe Rose, General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Rose:
div1.p:
Referring to the “Yellow Fever in Ceara,” enclosed in your
letter of December 2nd, received this morning:

Case 1. I cannot think that the diagnosis of yellow fever is
sustained by either the clinical history or autopsy. It may have
possibly been yellow fever developing in the course of some other
disease. Urine bloody, macroscopically, is practically unknown in
uncomplicated yellow fever. A case showing it should be a fulmi-
nant one--accessio pernicioso--dying, say, within 12 to 48 hours.

Cases 2 & 3. Not sufficient data given to judge. Case 3
may well have been yellow fever.

Case 4: I would judge to have been yellow fever, but clinical
history not as full as one would like.

I am puzzled by the findings of the Peste organism in Case 1
and in a man “ill of an identical disease” of Case 3. I wonder was
was
2.
the organism found run through animals--or was dependence placed on
its morphology and staining peculiarities. We were led astray in
Panama by the latter at one time.

The Report of the Yellow Fever Commission (Gorgas's) of 1916
might be read in this connection and a copy of it might be inter-
esting to Dr. Hackett.
